text:
today on hot thai kitchen 
we are making Panang curry

Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen today 
we're going to make a very popular curry called

panang curry now last week we made a Panang curry 
paste from scratch if you missed that video the

link will be at the end of this video and also in 
the description of this view and then today we're

going to actually turn this space that we just 
made into the actual curry so it's such a simple

curry so I'm just going to go through all the 
ingredients and then over to the stove and it's

done oh and you might be wondering I always give 
you a Thai lesson what does Panang mean Panang

doesn't actually have any sort of meaning in Thai 
language it's a name I'm sure there's a history to

the word if you know what it is please share it 
with me on our Facebook all right so let's look

at our ingredients so we've got a quarter of 
a cup of the curry paste that we just made if

you're using store-bought curry paste you probably 
need a little bit less because they usually have

a more concentrated consistency not as liquid 
as ours and then we've got coconut milk that's

separated into actually three parts quarter 
cup half cup and then a table two tablespoons

of coconut milk for garnish and you see why three 
separate measurements in a second other than that

we have of course our pork we're doing penang 
mole or penang pork today because that's the

most common type and you can make penang with 
just about anything really we've got 8 ounces

of pork tenderloin that I've sliced thinly into 
bite-sized pieces ok and you can use I'm using

tenderloin because it's tender but you can use 
other types of pork if you'd like or chicken and

I have a teaspoon and a half of fish sauce again 
this is an estimate if you're using store-bought

paste it's probably going to be a little bit 
saltier and you may need less and I also have

kaffir lime leaves which is very very important 
to this dish it's not a Penang if you don't have

kaffir lime leaves I have about five three i'm 
going to tear into chunks like this these have

actually been frozen and this we're going to 
throw into our curry the stems you can toss

okay and then well I guess I'll tear this one too 
so that we're going to throw into our curry and

then these ones I'm going to finely julienne for 
garnish I'm removing the stem you don't have to

but just makes it a little bit easier to eat just 
pull out the stem and then you're going to finely

finely julienne it as fine as you can I'm going 
to roll this up into a cigarette type thing and

then we're going to really really finely slice 
it when you think you can can't go any finer go

a little finer it would be really pretty trust me 
if you really put an effort into making this very

very thin if you have fresh lime leaves it'll 
be a little easier mine is actually previously

frozen so it's a bit wet but it's alright so good 
okay so we're going to keep that for our garnish

okay see how pretty that is for garnish okay and 
I also have a couple of slices of spiritual ease

or preachy fat that's also just going to be for 
garnish as well okay and you can use red bell

pepper or anything red will do and that is it 
that's all our ingredients so let's go to the

stove and cook this stuff so normally in my other 
curry videos I always start out with rendering the

coconut milk so that it separates oil then use 
that oil to saute the curry paste now a lot of

you have told me that oh I can't find the kind of 
coconut that separates my coconut doesn't separate

what do I do here's what you do I'm going to show 
you an alternative way to do it so you start out

with some vegetable oil in your pan and then you 
saw to your curry paste in it okay and when you

saute curry paste you don't have to wait for the 
oil to get hot before you add it it can heat up

together with the oil there are two benefits to 
that the paste will be you'll have more time to

sort of separate the pace because the paste does 
get a little bit it almost coagulates a little

bit as it heats up and also you don't have the 
risk of overheating the pan and then instantly

burning your curry paste so this is our Pro me pay 
so it's a little bit chunkier than store-bought

paste so you just want to do this until until the 
curry paste is dried up or if it starts to stick

or if it starts to kind of coagulate okay so now 
the pace is getting a little bit dry you're going

to add and in a non-stick pan it'll actually start 
to stick to the bottom a little bit and then and

then you're going to add about 1/4 cup of coconut 
milk and then you're going to cook this until the

coconut milk dries up and this will actually help 
some types of coconut milk separate more easily

the added oil in the beginning will kind 
of help shift the the equilibrium I guess

of the the coconut milk and make it separate 
more easily and just going to keep cooking

it until it dries up again and then at 
this point you're also going to add your

lime leaves which I almost forgot to add 
the oil is starting to separate already

you can start to see these the little bubbles 
around here starting to come out of the paste

alright at this point the oil has somewhat 
separated it's dried up again we're going

in with our pork and then you're just 
going to toss the pork together with

the paint quickly and then once it 
kind of pops up together to get it

all covered then you add your the rest 
of your coconut milk your fish sauce

and then I forgot to mention a little bit of sugar 
I'm going to do about a teaspoon and then we can

always taste and adjust from there teaspoon 
and a half I think actually okay you can also

do palm sugar if you like that would be the more 
traditional way but the sugar is right here so I'm

cheating a little and then now you're just going 
to finish cooking the pork and you're almost done

yay okay I think the pork looks done now so we're 
going to take this over there and plate it all

right we're going to come over here now Penang is 
a curry that's actually not very soupy so it's the

driest of all curry we even have a Thai word for 
that it's called click click which means not too

much sauce but a little bit of sauce you know just 
enough okay so Penang has some traditional garnish

that always goes with it all right which is a 
little bit of fresh coconut milk just to go on

top the kaffir lime leaf that we cut earlier and 
some prick Chifa or spur chilies to finish it off

and that is our Panang curry Penang is no good it 
by itself always with some jasmine rice and if you

enjoy the show please subscribe to the channel 
and for the full written recipe of all this

you can visit hot thai kitchen calm and I will 
see you next time for your next delicious Thai
you
